p: Alliaria petiolata is a widespread invader of North American forests that was introduced from multiple European populations (Durka et al. 2005). It produces several glucosinolate compounds, including sinigrin (Vaughn & Berhow 1999), which reduce populations of North American arbuscular mycorrhizal fungal (AMF) mutualists that most higher plants require for nutrient and water acquisition (Roberts & Anderson 2001; Stinson et al. 2006; Hale, Tonsor & Kalisz 2011). Sinigrin thus provides a competitive advantage to A. petiolata in interspecific competition by targeting the AMF symbionts of heterospecific plants, but this is expected to provide no benefit, or even be costly, in intraspecific competition as A. petiolata is non‐mycorrhizal (Lankau & Strauss 2007; Lankau 2008, 2012a, b).
